thread.title: 1,000-year-old Viking warrior found with weapons of war
thread.title_full: 1,000-year-old Viking warrior found with weapons of war | Daily Mail Online

author: Harry Pettit For Mailonline
title: 1,000-year-old Viking warrior found with weapons of war

organizations.name: university of leicester's school of archaeology

text:
One thousand years ago a Viking 'warrior of high status' was buried in a 17ft (5 metre) boat at a site in western Scotland.
Today, all that remains of the mysterious fighter are two teeth and a grave filled with artefacts, including a broad-bladed axe, a large sword and a bronze drinking horn.
Now the first detailed study of the stunning archaeological find has raised the remarkable possibility the body belongs to a female warrior rather than a male.
Scroll down for video
A Viking 'warrior of high status' has been found buried in Scotland. Some of the finds recovered from the Viking's grave are pictured here. From top left clockwise is a broad-bladed axe, shield boss, ringed pin and the hammer and tongs
FEMALE VIKINGS A ‘Shieldmaiden’ is a mythical female Viking who has chosen to fight as a warrior.
They appear in Viking folklore, and may have been the basis for the mythical ‘valkyries.’
The existence of female Viking warriors is heavily debated.
While there are many tales of individual women fighting in battles in Viking folklore, almost none speak of a community of trained female warriors like the Shieldmaiden myth.
Many historians argue that there isn’t enough hard evidence of the training and battling of female Vikings to conclude that they existed.
The research has found that the warrior was Scandinavian, meaning their burial at western Scotland's Swordle Bay laid them to rest a long way from home.
The report, in the journal Antiquity, says the sword and other grave goods might 'traditionally suggest' it was the burial of a man.
However, it also says: 'Any reading remains highly interpretive.'
Dr Oliver Harris, from the University of Leicester's School of Archaeology and Ancient History and co-director of the Ardnamurchan Transitions Project (ATP), said told Herald Scotland : 'The teeth themselves don't gender the person at all.
'So at the moment, we are left looking at the artefacts.
He said that a sword, axe and spear discovered in the grave suggest that a male warrior is buried in the grave.
'There are more Viking burials with swords that are men than women – if you want to play a statistical game, you would say it is probably a man,' he said.
'But you might choose to look at other grave goods, like the ladle or pan or sickle that don't necessarily send the same kind of message.'
They were placed in the boat with their shield on top of them, then the grave was filled to the top with stones.
Viking woman were known to be warriors, said Harris.
The warrior, of whom only two teeth and some fragments of bone are left, would have been buried in a Pagan ritual.
A set of strange isotopes in the warrior's teeth are also similar to a female found buried at Cnip on the Isle of Lewis, the report said.
The Viking's sword (top); was buried alongside them along with mineralised textile remains (right). Detail of the decoration after conservation can be seen to the left of the image
THE VIKINGS IN IRELAND The first attack by Vikings on Ireland was recorded around 795AD by Irish monks in the Annals of Ulster.
The first Vikings to arrive on Irish soil were from Scandinavia, they had set out to find and settle on new lands.
They had already settled in Scotland and, like Ireland, they began to settle within the local population.
The Vikings would remain in Ireland until the early 1,000's when they were driven out by an Irish rebellion.
But they left their mark on the island, helping the Irish to progress technologically with warships, weapons, and battle tactics.
They also helped to build Ireland's first towns such as Dublin, Cork and Waterford.
She was alive around the same time during the 10th Century.
Female Viking warriors could have fought as 'Shieldmaidens'.
They appear in Viking folklore, and may have been the basis for the mythical valkyries.
But the existence of female Viking warriors is heavily debated.
While there are many tales of individual women fighting in battles in Viking folklore, almost none speak of a community of trained female warriors like the Shieldmaiden myth.
But the artefacts found in the soldier's grave are a mix of Scandinavian and Irish goods, the research found.
The University of Leicester archaeologists who studied the site suggest that the warrior was an extensive traveller.
The burial site was originally discovered in 2011 at western Scotland's Swordle Bay. The burial represents the first excavation of an intact Viking boat burial by archaeologists on the UK
'The findings suggest a connection between Scandinavia and Ireland in the objects found, as well as information about the history of diet of the person buried here and their connections away from Swordle Bay,' archaeologist Dr Oliver Harris said.
Objects found at the site – including a sword, spearhead and 213 of the burial boat's rivets - indicate that the warrior was likely of a high status.
Other objects found at the site are connected to daily life such as cooking, work, farming and food production.
The archaeologists claim that the burial site is rich in symbolism due to its closeness to a Neolithic burial cairn - a human-made stack of stones.
Some of the cairn's stones may have been incorporated into the Viking's grave.
Other findings at the site include a single copper alloy ringed pin, thought to have been used to fasten a burial cloak or shroud.
Mineralised textile and wood remains were also discovered at the grave.
And archaeologists found a whetstone, used to cut and sharpen tools, made from Norwegian rock.
'The burial represents the first excavation of an intact Viking boat burial by archaeologists on the UK mainland and provides a significant addition to our knowledge of burial practices from this period,' Dr Harris said.
The research team added: 'Critically, when considering a burial like this, it is essential to remember that each of these objects, and each of these actions, was never isolated, but rather they emerge out of, and help to form, an assemblage that knits together multiple places, people and moments in time.'
The Viking warrior's body was first discovered in 2011.
The grave is thought to date from around 1,000AD at the height of the 'Second Viking Age'.
Pictured is a sketch of how the boat burial would have looked. Ships were a Viking's most prized possessions. If a high-born Viking did not die at sea he would be buried in a ship on land
Archaeologist Helena Gray with the sword and other artefacts found in the grave. The Viking vessel the warrior was buried in has almost completely rotted away
A sword, axe head and a bronze ring pin found at the burial site. The warrior, of whom only two teeth and some fragments of bone are left, would have been laid to rest in a Pagan ritual
For almost 200 years, from the end of the eighth century until the reign of Alfred the Great, Danish and Norwegian pirates had harassed and looted the British coast at will, and towards the end of that period moved further inland in a war of conquest.
But in the 870s, Alfred – and later his descendants – united England against the Viking invaders, driving them out of their English strongholds and back to Scandinavia.
They did not return for more than a century, and when they did, peace was shattered.
Dr Oliver Harris examines a sword with another archaeologist at the burial site
Dr Hannah Cobb, co-director of the Ardnamurchan Transitions Project, studies a viking sword
The Anglo-Saxons, by now ruled by the hapless Aethelred the Unready, were once again put to the sword, and huge amounts of money and goods were extorted from the native population in the form of Danegeld – a tax raised by the Vikings.
By 1016, the conquest was completed when Canute became the first Danish king of all England.
It is from this period that the tomb dates, and its elaborate contents show how wealthy the Vikings had become.
Many were converting to Christianity at the time, but from the artefacts laid to rest alongside him, it is clear this nobleman had been firmly committed to the old Norse religion.
Helena Gray, also a co-director of The Ardnamurchan Transitions Project, with an axe head found at the site
This viking's tooth was one of the many fascinating finds
The Viking vessel the warrior was buried in has almost completely rotted away.
Only some 200 metal rivets used to hold the boat together remain, with tiny splinters of wood attached.
The bronze drinking horn and weapons would have equipped the raider for Valhalla, the giant heavenly hall where the bravest Viking warriors believed they would spend eternity.
A bronze ring pin found at the site that was likely used to fasten a burial cape or shaw
Dr Hannah Cobb from Manchester University, who co-directed the 2011 excavation project, said: 'People have been fascinated by these boats for a long time but it is extremely rare to find a burial site intact, so it is of international importance.
'The artefacts and preservation also make this one of the most important Norse graves ever excavated in Britain.'
Viking boat burials were very rare because they were reserved for important figures, and many took place in coastal areas which have eroded away over the years, she added.
Britain's most famous ship burial, Sutton Hoo, is not Viking, but Anglo Saxon, and dates from centuries after the Vikings left the mainland.
THE VIKINGS Ships were a Viking's most prized possessions. If a high-born Viking did not die at sea he would be buried in a ship on land.
Vikings did not want to die in bed as this would mean thy would end up in a foggy underworld called Niflheim.
But if they died in battle they would go to glorious Valhalla.
Vikings believed that the world was flat, surrounded by sea and help up by a giant ash tree called Yggdrasil.
They would only bathe once a week.
Viking women were highly respected in Norse culture. They were free to choose their spouse and free to divorce.
